NewsLine.NewsLineText: SPORT-OLYMPICS-CHINA:Olympics-China seeks to boost world image with 2008 Games

body.p: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Sept 23 (Reuters) - China, which has struggled with its record in human rights, is looking to improve its image as it encourages businesses to get involved in the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.

"The Games will offer a unique opportunity for the development of China's sport industry and have a far-reaching influence on it," Sun Weijia, deputy director of Beijing's organising committee for the Games, told delegates at the World Sports Forum on Monday.
Beijing won the right to host the Games last year. China hopes the event will involve the entire country and attract business from all over the world.

With a population of 1.2 billion, business opportunities abound but, with three-quarters of the country living in rural areas and earning low incomes, the issue of accessibility, particularly with regard to pricing, is a key concern.

"We will make the Games available for all people," said Weijia. "The policy for tickets is still in study so that is one of our objectives, that most people will have the means to get access to the Games," he said.
China is acutely aware of the challenges it will face in the coming six years, not least in providing the country with a legacy after the Games.
"The Olympic Games needs 37 stadiums -- there are 19 still to be built. These venues after the event will be open to the public," said Weijia.
"Staging it will be of major importance to the national sport programmes."
In the run-up to the Games, China is hosting other major sporting events including the ATP Tennis Masters tournament in Shanghai in November and the women's soccer World Cup next year.
But the Olympic Games will be the litmus test as far as the country's global image is concerned.
But Weijia said he believed that by choosing China to stage the Games the country had the support of the international community.

Michael Payne, marketing director of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) who was also at the Forum, said the IOC had never seen such a level of interest in the early stages of the Games' build-up as has been the case with China.
"It is an opportunity for China in terms of presenting itself to the world as well as for business opportunities -- the Games will present a platform to fast-track that development," Payne said.
Mark McCormack, chairman of the sports marketing firm IMG, said China's hosting of the Oympic Games showed that it was becoming more of a world citizen.
"The Chinese recognise the problems they've had in the past over human rights issues," McCormack said.
